name: AWS.Core.Http
comment:
AWS requests and responses.


# Table of Contents

  - [Requests](#requests)
  - [Body](#body)

Examples assume the following imports:

    import Json.Decode


# Requests

@docs Request, request, addHeaders, addQuery, setResponseParser, send, Method, Path


# Body

@docs Body, MimeType, emptyBody, stringBody, jsonBody

aliases.name: Request
aliases.comment: Holds an unsigned AWS HTTP request.

values.name: addHeaders
values.comment:
Appends headers to an AWS HTTP unsigned request.

    request GET "/" emptyBody Json.Decode.value
        |> addHeaders
            [ ( "x-custom-1", "value 1" )
            , ( "x-Custom-2", "value 2" )
            ]
        |> addHeaders
            [ ( "x-custom-3", "value 3" )
            ]
        |> toString
    --> "{ method = \"GET\", path = \"/\", body = Empty, decoder = <decoder>, headers = [(\"x-custom-1\",\"value 1\"),(\"x-Custom-2\",\"value 2\"),(\"x-custom-3\",\"value 3\")], query = [], responseParser = Nothing }"
values.type: List ( String, String ) -> AWS.Core.Http.Request a -> AWS.Core.Http.Request a

values.name: addQuery
values.comment:
Appends query arguments to an AWS HTTP unsigned request.

    request GET "/" emptyBody Json.Decode.value
        |> addQuery
            [ ( "key1", "value 1" )
            , ( "Key2", "value 2" )
            ]
        |> addQuery
            [ ( "key3", "value 3" )
            ]
        |> toString
    --> "{ method = \"GET\", path = \"/\", body = Empty, decoder = <decoder>, headers = [], query = [(\"key1\",\"value 1\"),(\"Key2\",\"value 2\"),(\"key3\",\"value 3\")], responseParser = Nothing }"
values.type: List ( String, String ) -> AWS.Core.Http.Request a -> AWS.Core.Http.Request a

values.name: emptyBody
values.comment: Create an empty body.

values.name: jsonBody
values.comment:
Create a body containing a JSON value.

This will automatically add the `Content-Type: application/json` header.

values.name: request
values.comment:
Create an AWS HTTP unsigned request.

    request GET "/" emptyBody Json.Decode.value
        |> toString
    --> "{ method = \"GET\", path = \"/\", body = Empty, decoder = <decoder>, headers = [], query = [], responseParser = Nothing }"
values.type: AWS.Core.Http.Method -> AWS.Core.Http.Path -> AWS.Core.Http.Body -> Json.Decode.Decoder a -> AWS.Core.Http.Request a

values.name: send
values.comment: Signs and sends an AWS Request.
values.type: AWS.Core.Service.Service -> AWS.Core.Credentials.Credentials -> AWS.Core.Http.Request a -> Task.Task Http.Error a

values.name: setResponseParser
values.comment: Set a parser for the entire Http.Response. Overrides the request decoder.
values.type: (Http.Response String -> Result.Result String a) -> AWS.Core.Http.Request a -> AWS.Core.Http.Request a

values.name: stringBody
values.comment:
Create a body with a custom MIME type and the given string as content. stringBody "text/html" "

Hello

"

name: AWS.Core.Service
comment:
AWS service configuration.


# Table of Contents

  - [Types](#types)
  - [Constructors](#constructors)
  - [Property Setters](#property-setters)
  - [Protocols](#protocols)
  - [Signatures](#signatures)
  - [Timestamp Formats](#timestamp-formats)
  - [Attributes](#attributes)


# Types

@docs Service, ApiVersion, Region, Protocol, Signer, TimestampFormat, Endpoint


# Constructors

Use either one of these to create a service definition.

@docs defineGlobal, defineRegional


# Property Setters

@docs setJsonVersion, setSigningName, setTargetPrefix, setTimestampFormat, setXmlNamespace, toDigitalOceanSpaces


# Protocols

Use these functions to specify the AWS request protocol used by the service.

@docs ec2, json, query, restJson, restXml


# Signatures

Use these functions to specify the signature version used by a service.

@docs signV4, signS3


# Timestamp Formats

Use these functions to specify the timestamp format used by a service.

@docs iso8601, rfc822, unixTimestamp


# Attributes

These functions are exposed so that [AWS.Core.Http](AWS-Core-Http) can properly
sign requests. They can be useful for debugging, testing, and logging, but
otherwise are not required.

@docs endpointPrefix, region, host, signer, targetPrefix, jsonContentType, acceptType

aliases.name: Protocol
aliases.comment:
Enumerates AWS request protocols.

See [Protocols](#protocols) for constructors.

aliases.name: Region
aliases.comment:
An AWS region string.

For example `"us-east-1"`.

aliases.name: Signer
aliases.comment:
Enumerates AWS signature versions.

See [Signatures](#signatures) for constructors.

aliases.name: TimestampFormat
aliases.comment:
Enumerates timestamp formats.

See [Timestamp Formats](#timestamp-formats) for constructors.

values.name: acceptType
values.comment: Gets the service Accept header value.

values.name: defineGlobal
values.comment:
Creates a global service definition.

    let
        service = defineGlobal "sts" "2011-06-15" query signV4
            (setXmlNamespace "https://sts.amazonaws.com/doc/2011-06-15/")
    in
    ( service |> endpointPrefix
    , service |> host
    , service |> targetPrefix
    )
    --> ( "sts"
    --> , "sts.amazonaws.com"
    --> , "AWSSTS_20110615"
    --> )
values.type: String -> AWS.Core.Service.ApiVersion -> AWS.Core.Service.Protocol -> AWS.Core.Service.Signer -> (AWS.Core.Service.Service -> AWS.Core.Service.Service) -> AWS.Core.Service.Service

values.name: defineRegional
values.comment:
Creates a regional service definition.

    let
        acm = defineRegional "acm" "2015-12-08" json signV4
            (setJsonVersion "1.1" >> setTargetPrefix "CertificateManager")
        service = acm "ca-central-1"
    in
    ( service |> endpointPrefix
    , service |> host
    , service |> targetPrefix
    )
    --> ( "acm"
    --> , "acm.ca-central-1.amazonaws.com"
    --> , "CertificateManager"
    --> )

Your client library should not provide the region. Instead it should expose
a function `Region -> Service` by leaving out the last argument.
values.type: String -> AWS.Core.Service.ApiVersion -> AWS.Core.Service.Protocol -> AWS.Core.Service.Signer -> (AWS.Core.Service.Service -> AWS.Core.Service.Service) -> AWS.Core.Service.Region -> AWS.Core.Service.Service

values.name: ec2
values.comment: EC2 request protocol.

values.name: endpointPrefix
values.comment: Name of the service.

values.name: host
values.comment: Service endpoint as a hostname.

values.name: iso8601
values.comment: Use the timestamp format ISO8601.

values.name: json
values.comment: JSON request protocol.

values.name: jsonContentType
values.comment: Gets the service JSON content type header value.

values.name: query
values.comment: QUERY request protocol.

values.name: region
values.comment: Service region.

values.name: restJson
values.comment: REST_JSON request protocol.

values.name: restXml
values.comment: REST_XML request protocol.

values.name: rfc822
values.comment: Use the timestamp format RCF822.

values.name: setJsonVersion
values.comment:
Set the JSON apiVersion.

Use this if `jsonVersion` is provided in the metadata.

values.name: setSigningName
values.comment:
Set the signing name for the service.

Use this if `signingName` is provided in the metadata.

values.name: setTargetPrefix
values.comment:
Set the target prefix for the service.

Use this if `targetPrefix` is provided in the metadata.

values.name: setTimestampFormat
values.comment:
Set the timestamp format for the service.

Use this if `timestampFormat` is provided in the metadata.

values.name: setXmlNamespace
values.comment:
Set the XML namespace for the service.

Use this if `xmlNamespace` is provided in the metadata.

values.name: signS3
values.comment:
A variation on V4 signing for use with AWS S3.

See <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/sig-v4-header-based-auth.html#canonical-request>

values.name: signV4
values.comment: Use V4 signing.

values.name: signer
values.comment: Service signature version.

values.name: targetPrefix
values.comment: Set the target prefix.

values.name: toDigitalOceanSpaces
values.comment:
Use Digital Ocean Spaces as the backend service provider.

Changes the way hostnames are resolved.

values.name: unixTimestamp
values.comment: Use the timestamp format UnixTimestamp.

name: AWS
comment:
AWS SDK for elm.

The elm-aws-core package provides functions and types that facilitate making
HTTP requests to AWS services. Use it to create user-friendly clients to
specific AWS services.


## Modules in this package

  - [AWS.Core.Service](AWS-Core-Service): Create a service definition. Every service client should define its own `Service` definition.
  - [AWS.Core.Credentials](AWS-Core-Credentials): Create AWS credentials used to sign requests.
  - [AWS.Core.Http](AWS-Core-Http): Create requests, sign, and send them. Signing and sending a request requires both a `Service` and `Credentials`.
  - [AWS.Core.Enum](AWS-Core-Enum): Many AWS services define enumerations. This small module provides functions to convert from Elm types to string values.


## Usage example

    import AWS.Core.Credentials as Credentials
    import AWS.Core.Http as Http exposing (Method(..))
    import AWS.Core.Service as Service
    import Json.Decode
    import Task

    let
        creds =
            Credentials.fromAccessKeys
                "ACCESS KEY ID"
                "SECRET ACCESS KEY"
        service =
            Service.defineGlobal
                "sts"
                "2011-06-15"
                Service.query
                Service.signV4
                (Service.setXmlNamespace "https://sts.amazonaws.com/doc/2011-06-15/")
        handler =
            \result ->
                case result of
                    Ok someValue ->
                        -- someValue is what you get from the decoder
                        -- that is provided to the request call below.
                        -- In this case, it would be an Int because
                        -- we are using Json.Decode.int as the decoder.
                        someValue /= -1
                    Err err ->
                        -- err is an Http.Error
                        -- See: http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/http/latest/Http#Error
                        False
    in
    Http.request
        GET
        "/some/path"
        Http.emptyBody
        Json.Decode.int
        |> Http.send service creds
        |> Task.attempt handler
        |> (/=) Cmd.none
    --> True

@docs version

values.name: version
values.comment:
elm-aws-core package version.

    AWS.version
    --> "1.1.0"

name: AWS.Core.Enum
comment:
Convert AWS enums values to basic values

@docs toString, toFloat

values.name: toFloat
values.comment:
Convert an AWS enum value to a float

    Enum.toFloat CacheClusterSize_0_5 -- Ok 0.5

values.name: toString
values.comment:
Convert an AWS enum value to a string

    Enum.toString IntegrationType_HTTP_PROXY -- Ok "HTTP_PROXY"

name: AWS.Core.Credentials

values.name: accessKeyId
values.comment: Gets the access key.

values.name: fromAccessKeys
values.comment: Create AWS credentials given an access key and secret key.

values.name: secretAccessKey
values.comment: Gets the secret.

values.name: sessionToken
values.comment: Gets the session token.

values.name: setSessionToken
values.comment: Set the session token.
